div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,598] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905
“A good article recommends itself.”
HOWIES Butter is no exception
Awarded Twelve 1st Prize Medals at the Khedivial Agricultural Show 1902, 1903 and 1905.
GIVE IT A TRIAL.
Address: Shubra Road, Cairo. 24-5-907

div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: A perfect food is Bovril—it nourishes, stimulates and reinvigorates. Bovril is of great value for all to whom strength and endurance are a vital necessity. Its regular use is a permanent protection against the dangers of fcolds, chills and diseases.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to entre into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness. 28283A-30-10-906

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1906.

div.head: THE LATEST POLITICAL DISEASE.
div.p: ‘‘The Morning Post" says : "The latest political disease is ‘Pan-Mania’ .... Fundamen- tally, of course, the prefix ’Pan’ indicates that all the scattered parts of the race, nation, country, or religion are to be united, but very considerable variations from this ‘motif’ are permitted. . . . Two of the greatest of the ‘Pans’ overlap very seriously—Pan-Germans in Brazil and the Argentine mast be difficult to place in a Pan-American system. When we come to the second great ‘Pan’ we are on firmer ground. Pan-Germanism is not all coherent, but it has a solid foundation. The Pan-German cult expands itself in one direction to recover for Germany (not intellectually only but politically) the peoples of Teutonio stock who are not Germane (though they speak the German tongue the Swiss and Austrians, and the Low German peoples, the Dutch, Belgians (and even the Boers) while in another direction it spreads to the Colonies of Germans on German soil, and even to the small German settlements in towns and countries which are not German. Pan-Germanism has an organisation not confined to one body bot ramifying through hundreds of associations, political, economic, and even religions. They are not called Pan-Germanic societies, nor are they openly affiliated to the League which bears that name, bat-they are informed with the Pan-German spirit, helped with Pan- German foods, and (with different degrees of zeal) press for the seemed. Pan Germanism is not a political party in Germany, but a cult or ideal which can be adopted by any party. In Austria, however, the Pan-Germans actually go to the polls and sit in Parliament as such. They are at present the only ‘Pans' of any kind to do so. Pan-Slavism, in its broadest sense, as implying a league or union of the Slav peoples, is little more than an impious aspiration. The Czechs, who are the most advanced of all the Slav races, would always want to lead, and this privilege would never be accorded by any of the others. The elimination of Russia (for the time being at all events) precludes the idea of a Pan Slav union in the Near East under her august patronage and protection. Such as it is, however, Pan Slavism altogether overshadows the little Pan-Hellenic propaganda which is Greece’s latest contribution to the happiness of the world. Pan-Buddhism has a powerful propaganda to day in China, which aims at rousing the national and racial pride of the Orientals and inducing them to develop on their own lines and not on Western ones. The singular feature of Pan-Islam is that, as a name, an idea, a ‘motif to be interpreted by each man after his kind, it is at present uniting a very considerable proportion of the world's population, and, unlikely other ‘Pan,’ it has no limitation, ethnographic, geographic, or national.”

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The second performance of the ballet Les Poupées Animées, which was to have been given this afternoon at the San Stefano Theatre, has been cancelled owing to the indisposition of several of the children taking part. The usual children’s al fresco ball will be held this afternoon, with the Bracale Orchestra. Chocolate will be given to the children of subscribers. The following is the menu of to-morrow's dinner : —
Consommé doubla glacé.
Dames da bar A la Kiborimne
Mignons de bœuf Nivernaiw
Pilaff A U Ktrasbourgvoiaa
Haricots varia A l'anglaise
Dindonneau réti Broche
Malade do Saison
Parfait au Moka
Patisserie assortie
Grand Dessert

div.head: LEAVES FOR CONSTANTINOPLE.
div.p: Vienna, September 13.
H.H. the Khedive has left for Constantinople. (Havas)

div.head: HIGH COMMISSIONER'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: Paris, September 13.

M. Bourgeois has sent a diplomatist to Aix- les-Baine to announce to Prince George that the Consuls at Canea will communicate the Prince’s Note of the 14th August, concerning the appointment of the High Commissioner, to the Cretan Assembly. (Havas)

div.head: ASSEMBLY OF CONSTITUTIONAL DEMOCRATS.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 13.
M. Stolypin has refused the Constitutional Democrats permission to meet in congress here. The assembly will therefore be held in Finland or Sweden. ( Reuter)

div.head: "TIMES" AND CHINESE ASSURANCES.
div.p: London, September 13.

The "Times” strongly comments on the inadequacy of the Chinese assurances with regard to the position of Sir Robert Hart The paper adds : “If Great Britain accepts those assurances as the best solution discoverable we shall not have to wait long for equally flagrant breaches of treaty rights.” (Reuter)

div.head: FOREIGN CRITICS ON MANCEUVRES.
div.p: Berlin, September 13.

Foreign critics at the German manœuvres were impressed by the endurance shown by the troops, hot were surprised et the close formation adopted "by the infantry for frontal attacks and the absence of head covering in trenches, in spits of the lessons of the Russo- Japanese war. ( Reuter )

div.head: ENGLAND INVADED BY IRELAND.
div.p: London, September 13.

The army manœnvres, conducted by General Sir John French, with naval officers cooperating, have begun at Aldershot. The idea of the manceuvres is the invasion of England by Ireland after having defeated the fleet. (R.)

div.head: ARMY GENERAL STAFF.
div.p: London, September 13.
An Army Order of the day constitutes General Staff consisting of 57 officers at head quarters and 114 in commands in districts. (Reuter)

div.head: UNITED STATES AND CUBA.
div.p: New York, September 13.
Two more warships have been despatched to Cuba. (Reuter)

div.head: DEATH OF PRINCE ALBERT.
div.p: Berlin, September 13.
Prince Albrecht of Prussia, Regent of Brunswick, is dead. (Reuter)

The Regent of the Duchy of Brunswick, Prince Frederick William Nicholas Albert of Prussia, was the son of the Kaiser's great- uncle and was born in Berlin in 1987. He had been Regent of Brunswick since 1885. He married in 1854 the Princess of Sixe-Altenburg, by whom he had three sons.

div.head: British Soldier Injured.
div.p: A British private was knocked over and injured by a tram on Tuesday near the El Tewtikieh Pharmacy, Cairo.

div.head: British Man-of-War.
div.p: H.M.S Venus, coming from Port Said to Alexandria. was sighted by the Kom el-Dik signalling station as we went to press.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: To-day’s bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria and another at Suez. The patient at Alexandria is a native living in the Customhouse quarter.

div.head: The Sudan.
div.p: A new work on the Sudan by Dr. E. A. Wallis Budge is to be published shortly, entitled "The Egyptian Sudan, its History and Monuments.”

div.head: Gum Arabic.
div.p: At the London gum auctions on the 6th inst. the only gum arabic sold was 22 bags of Australians. Its quality was a fair glassy red, a little blocky, at 60s.

div.head: Mex-les-Eains.
div.p: At 5.30 this afternoon, the Compagnia Vul- canica dei Diavoli Rossi, vocalists and instrumentalists, will make their debut at the Max Casino, to which admission is free.

div.head: Esbekieh Court Scandals.
div.p: The recent revelations as to embezzlements in the Esbekieh Summary Court have led the Cairo Parquet to arrest Ali Abdel Raouf Eff., a dark of the court, who is suspected of the defalcations.

div.head: Execution.
div.p: Hassan Ali El-Adli, of Rahmanieh, Behera Moudirieh, who has been sentenced to death for the murder of his uncle, aunt, and their servant, as already related in our columns, will be executed in Hadra prison on Monday next at 7.30 a.m.

div.head: Egyptian Salt and Soda.
div.p: Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to allow the following security to be quoted in the Official List : Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Limited— Farther issue of 150,000 Ordinary Shares of XI each fully paid.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Club.
div.p: The committee inform us that the club's new floating bath is ready for use, and that a steam launch will leave the Marisa to-morrow at 3.15 p.m., for Rassel Tin. Members and friends are requested to meet in full force, especially those competing in the sports, for the purpose of having their times taken.

div.head: Sudden Death.
div.p: While Mr. Constantine Evangelidis was taking a cup of coffee this morning in the Café du Nil near the Alexandria Bourse, he felt a slight pain in his head, so he walked to Mr. Ruelberg’s pharmacy to get some medicine. A doctor was called, but before the letter's arrival he had expired from heart disease.

div.head: Not Wanted.
div.p: The Cairo police found an infant of the female sex lying in Sharia El-Nubi, Mousky quarter, two days ago. Close beside it was a slip of paper with the following inscription in Greek : “This child is 20 days old and has not been baptised." The babe was taken to the Foundlings' Home, where she received the name of Anisseh Abdalla.

div.head: Prince Line.
div.p: The gross profits for the year ended June 30 amounted to £109,684. After allowing for renewals and including £1,743 brought forward there is a disposable balance of £71,820. The directors devote £40,000 to depreciation, and propose a final dividend at the rate of 5 per cent, carrying forward £1,745. The distribution was the same a year ago.

div.head: The Shoubra Crime.
div.p: The communiqué of the French Consulate, exculpating M. Paillard, senior, of the 8houbra crime, by an alibi, came as a surprise to Cairo society, which would not now be taken aback were Paillard, junior, to have the same favour bestowed on him. The dilatoriness in the enquiry is attributed by the French Consulate to the Native Court which has not yet officially communicated the résults of its enquiry.

div.head: Ship Cut In Two.
div.p: While on the usual run from Jaffa to Port Said, the Messageries steamer Sénégal, which reached Port Said on Wednesday, ran down a sailing craft, and cat her in two before she could stop. The crew of the vessel, seven in number, escaped in the dinghy, and were picked up. One of them was hurt by the collision, but not seriously. The Sénégal was delayed four hours by the accident, which occurred sixty miles off Port Said and at two a.m. The sunken vessel carried no masthead lights.

div.head: Cairo Season.
div.p: Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt). Limited, have issued a useful and artistic handbook giving the fullest details as to their arrangements for the coming tourist season in Egypt and on the Nile. To anyone contemplating a visit to Nile-land, this excellently got up little publication is a valuable vade mecum giving as it does useful information regarding the many spots which may be visited and the varions itineraries followed by the ubiquitous Cook. The pamphlet contains a host of pretty illustrations.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be nonsuited by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE PROPOSED BANQUET.
div.p: The native press, having exhausted itself in discussing the many and various problems connected with the treatment of Helbawi Bey by Prince Mohamed Aly Paras, and the alleged secret interview of Abon Shadi Bey with Mr. Findlay, has now found a fresh source of inspiration in the approaching banquet, which is to be given in honour of Kamel's return to his native land. We, however, deeply regret to notice that many of the leading journalistic luminaries of the nationalist newspaper world appear to be disposed to skulk in their tents in view of the splendid ovation that is to be given to the great protagonist of Egyptian nationalism. The lesser lights of the vernacular Anglophobe press naturally feel rather out of it, for "A1 Minbar” and its brethren will suffer au eclipse when the editor of "Al Lews" returns in all his glory. "Misr" is of opinion that the banquet is premature, and that it should be postponed until the English have withdrawn from Egypt and the country has obtained complete independence ! A journalist writes to "Al Watan" to protest against the proposed banquet. He states that the Pasha does not deserve snob an honor, at he has not rendered any services to the country, but is merely working for his own ends. The writer goes on to state that he has only distinguished himself by arousing bitterness between Moslem and Christian, and that if such a banquet be given, it will lead to a very bad impression in England. The same paper publishes a telegram from Tantah to the effect that a large number of native notables there have decided to oppose the proposed scheme for honoring the Pasha. An amusiug example of nationalist fervor is seen in the proposal of one of the supporters of the Pasha that the "pièce de resistance" at the forthcoming banquet should be an Egyptian camel in honor of that serviceable creature's namesake. Whether one or more of these quadrupeds is to be cooked for the occasion we do not know, bat sorely one would not be enough to go round among the many supporters of Kamel, who will flock to the banquet. The symbolic signification involved in snob a dish will probably only be divulged to the initiates, bat, on the other hand, the idea may have been merely suggested by the simple coincidence of the names. No doubt this problem will be dis- cussed ad nauscam in the columns of our contemporaries, for the bill of fare is already leading to criticism. The idea of a "national" repast pare and simple has not met with universal approval, for it is recognized that if the banquet is solely confined to Egyptian dishes and drinks, the mena will hardly be to the taste of the hero of the evening, who has been accustomed in London to the gastronomic delicacies of the Carlton Hotel. The idea of an essentially 'nationalistic" bill of fare is a good one, bat it is somewhat difficult to realise. Possibly a compromise may be effected by varying the monotony with a few Jew Turkish dishes. We might venture to suggest a via media in the shape of a Pan-Islamic feast. which could thus embrace a variety of dishes, Moorish, Algerian, Tunisian, etc. Surely this would be the most simple way out of the difficulty.

div.head: "AL LEWA" IN ENGLISH.
div.p: Mustapha Fasha Kamel’s new English daily paper, which is to begin its existence shortly at Cairo, is from all accounts destined to be a very remarkable sample of Egyptian journalistic enterprise. The Egyptian "patriot" has engaged an Hibernian patriot to be the Editor- in-chief of his new Anglophobe organ, and the arrival of this Irish journalist is shortly expec- ted. A special feature of the Pasha’s English paper will be a series of articles by Little Englander Members of Parliament.

div.head: NIGHT OPERATIONS OF GARRISON.
div.p: Night operations will again be practised by the British garrison in Cairn on the night of the I7th-I8th inst. The garrison will be divided into two opposing forces, a defence force, under command of Lieut.-Col. C. J. Markham, 1st King's Royal Rifle Corps, composed of a detachment of R.G.A. (with 4 mountain guns), a detachment of Royal Engineers, and the 1st K.R.R. Corps, and an attacking force, under Lieut-Col. J. H. Gideon, 1st Lancashire Fusiliers.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malts, with passenger , mails, and general cargo. The Moss liner Seti sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday, and is due herew on or about the 26th inst. With passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: Hamburg & Anglo-American Nile Company.
div.p: River Transport of Goods between Alexandria and Cairo.
Three Sailings a-week.
Agents at Alexandria
ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE CO. LTD.
Instrument Concerts
Every Night
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
Alexandria
From 6 to 12 p.m.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah.

div.head: TWO COMPETING ROUTES.
div.p: It has been implied that a transit of 29 ½ days between London and Hong Kong by the Canadian route would, if maintained, establish a permanent acceleration of seven days as compared with the transit viâ the Suez Canal. So far back as 1898 the scheduled transit for the English mail to Hong Kong from London, via Suez, was 18 ½ days—one day lees than the promised westerly transit—while delivery by the Suez route has in practice invariably been made in advance of schedule time. Moreover, while the present scheduled transit for the Suez route is 27 ½ days, the actual carriage of the mail between London and Hong-Kong is made in less than 26 days—three to four days better, it is claimed, than the new "record" claimed for the Canadian route. It will be remembered that the promoters of the Baghdad Railway have never ceased their efforts to interest Preach finance in that enterprise, and that financial influences in France have occasionally resisted the opposition made to the scheme on political grounds. These facts, the “Times" Paris correspondent says, give special interest to the attention attracted in financial circles in Paris by the discussion of the question by the Dross of Calcutta and Bombay, which contends that the Baghdad Railway will never be a very brilliant affair from a business standpoint and can never seriously damage the Suez Canal.

div.head: GERMAN FLAG ON THE NILE.
div.p: The German flag will not be flown instead of the Stars and Stripes by the steamers of the Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company, but will be flown together with the British end American flags. As a result of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company’s fusion with the Hamburg-America Line, the former Company is building two new steamers, the Germania and the Nubia. There is no intention of building two more vessels of a similar type for the season 1907-1908.

div.head: DISAPPOINTING RESULTS.
div.p: A Bombay Government resolution, reviewing the results of the cultivation of Egyptian cotton in Sind daring 1905, remarks that they not so promising as originally anticipated, owing partly to the unfavourable character of the season, but perhaps more largely to the very partial adoption only by the Sindhi zamindars of the Egyptian methods of cultiva- tion, which are far more expensive and laborious than the indigenous methods to which they are accustomed. Owing to the peculiar circumstances of the province it is feared that considerable time will elapse before the imperfect indigenous methods are supplanted by the Egyptian. Patience and persuasion are therefore commended to the authorities There was apparently some difficulty in disposing of last year's Indian "Egyptian” crop in India only one firm purchasing it in any large quantity at fair prices ; and these were lower than the prices obtained for the sample hairs sent borne by the authorities to Liverpool. The Government trust that, with the assurance obtained from Liverpool of the high quality of the cotton and the larger quantity to be grown this year, better prices will be secured and more buyers will come forward.

div.head: A SUDAN HERO.
div.p: Lieutenant-General Sir Archibald Hunter, Chief of the Western Command, India who last week celebrated his fiftieth birthday, has rendered distinguished service to the army, notably in-Egypt, where be spent thirteen years. Ha participated in five campaigns on the banks of the Nile including the battles of Atbara and Khartoum. He secured the rank of Major-General at the age of forty, and ii became a K.C.B. During the siege of Ladysmith he was second in command to Sir George White, and he distinguished himself during the sortie of Dec. 7, 1899. His decorations and other rewards during his service from 1885 to 1900 are four medals, a dozen clasps, a bronze star, the Medjidieh and Osmanieh Orders, the D.S.O., eleven mentions in dispatches, four special promotions, and the thanks of Parliament. He carries two wounds - one severe - received on the Nile.

EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.
F. Phillips & Co.
LADIES’ TAILORS.

CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discustion.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST, LIMITED.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir,— In your issue of the 27th August, you were good enough to publish my letter to you on the subject of the Egyptian Land and General Trust. Io that letter I told the shareholders that there was no time to lose. I bad not, however, an idea that I was offering this caution with so much reason as now appears. By the time this reaches you any shareholders now in Egypt will be in possession of a notice fed London, 4th September, to the effect that a general meeting will be held here on the 14th idem. From the circumstances of the this will probably resolve itself into another unimportant London gathering to deal with important issues. At this meeting we are to be told how "the Board are now dealing with offers which appear to be favourable for the extending the operations of the company”; of the arrangement under which "Mr. Mack is to take charge of the business of the company in Egypt," and presumably of the disappearance of Mr. Lonsdorfer from the list of directors. Many of us will, I am sure, be anxious to hear :— (a) How money, is to be found tor extending operations ? (b) What opportunities now exist comparable with those which have been the making of the "Estates," 'Delta Lands," and others ? (c) Why we are once more deprived of valuable local experience ? I am still, only more so,
”One of the Unfortunates.”
London, 6th September.

div.head: ROYAL INNISKILLING FUSILIERS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir,—IN reply to the interesting letter of one of your correspondents in connection with the picture which appeared in ‘The Sphere” of Jane 16th last of British soldiers surrounding the Sphinx, I beg to inform you that while it is true that this interesting picture was published in The Sphere,'' our journal carefully guarded itself from the statement that the men actually on the Sphinx belonged to the Lancashire Position. We merely committed ourselves to the generalization that British soldier on reaching Egypt were naturally interested in the Sphinx, and that the Lancashire were specially so in view of their services in the campaign of 1801. Not for worlds would one hurt the feelings of such a gallant regiment as the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, whos heroic deeds have found their most eloquent champion in Lord Mucaulay, and whose services in Egypt in 1801 are also immortalised in their colours. -
I am, dear Sir, Yours truely,
The Editor
"The Sphere" Great New St. Fetter Lane.
London, E.C., September 5.

div.head: NILE FLOOD.
div.p: According to the “Sudan Times,’’ the high Nile of this year has been unprecedented in the modern history of the Sudan. Before Mahdism, however, higher Niles have been known. Sometimes we are told, the waters of the Blue Nile threatened to overflow Khartoum, that the draining of rain water by natural methods was impracticable. An artificial stratagem had to be resorted to. All water was drained into a large "birka” near the river over a dyke by a steam lifting machine.

A native notable of experience informs us that a further rise of one metre over the present levels is cemetery before the “huge" lands can be naturally irrigated. He is confident of a farther heavy rainfall in this month which will result in the realization of this occurrence.

A heavy rainfall occurred on Monday, the 3d instant accompanied by a severe thunderstorm. The rain was typically tropical in its volume The lightning and thunder continued far into the night, the storm subsiding early on Tuesday morning. The rainfall amounted to 16 millimeters On the 29th of August the Nile level at Rosaires was 19.20. A rise of one metre and ninety centimeters occurred on the 1st inst. When the level readings were 21.10. This sudden rise gives reason for anxiety and we understand that the Governemnt is taking the necessary steps to protect Khartonm from its effect.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Poor quelques valeur» la baisse s’aeoe mais en général on est assez ferma La National Bank petd 1/8 à 96 3/16, 1* Cassa di Soon to 3/4 à 999 3/4, et U Delta Land 1/39 à 8 1/4. La Banqn* d'Orieot recule jaïqii’à 181, prix anqnel elle est complètement délaissée. 8i le Trost se maintient relativement à 1 7/16, il n'en est pas de même de la Bailding Lands qui eet maintenant offerte à 5. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is stated that Prince Omar Pasha Tous- soun will vary probable be appointed Guardian of the children of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, and that the Khedive and the Government have approved of the selection.
It is stated that the insurance money of the late Prince Mohamed Bay Ibrahim, which it was asserted, really amounted to £1000 000, was set aside by the deceased for the benefit of his male children.
It is stated that the Khedivah Mother has abandoned her intention of making the pilgrimage to Mecca this year.

Sir Ernest Cassel has taken delivery of a 45 horse-power Mercedes automobile with limou sine saloon coach work by Moral et Grammar The interior of the vehicle is handsomely equipped, and contains various devices for the comfort of the passengers.

Mr. Chataway, the Administrator of the Alexandria Municipality, is at present in Eng- land, and was to have returned to Egypt on the 25th inst. We regret to learn, however, that be is suffering from the attack of intermittent Malta fever. He has contracted the fever here and has been unable to shake it off at home and is still very weak. It is doubtful therefore whether be will be able to return at the date of the expiry of his leave.
Mr. James Hewat, American Consular Agent at Alexandria, is due back from England by the S.S. City of Oxford on Sunday next.
M. and Mme Elie M. Cattani are staying at the Hotel du Vieux Doelen, The Hague.
M. Adrian Giro is among the visitors at the Amstel Hotel, Amsterdam.
Mr. G. J. Hornblower, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, has obtained leave of absence on private affairs for forty days.

Rear-Admiral William Carnegie Codrington Forsyth, whose death took place last week at Llanfoethen, North Wales at the age of 57, was present at the bombardment of Alexandria, July, 1882, as lien tenant of the Invincible and subsequently landed with a reconnoitering party during the horning of the city. For this service he was promoted to commander, and received the Egyptian medal, with clasp, for Alexandria, and the Khedive's bronze star. His commission as captain bore date December 31. 1889, and that of rear-admiral. May 30, 1903. He retired from active service in the following year.

Apostoloa, M. R Meggier, Mohamed Aly bey, M. Spiro Condo- leoo, Mme Josephine Monies, M. Joseph Salem, M. Gordon, M. Criçton Goolmas Mme Etpma- nuel, M. et Mme Samarase, Mme Barbiteet sa fills RR Bdward BcyX Blias, Mme et M. C. Pisodimos M. Askar, Manr Askar et fils, M. C. Comanos M. Anaguostou, Mme Umitrion et sa fills Mms Ida Pales, M. Zaldari. M. Aeitue M. Tsakars M. Lytsioas, M. Veoaris, M. Morporgo, M. J. Capernavo, M. et Mme Qbedsfdjian, Mme Portuoali bey et fille M. et Mme Poliseni, M. D. Axels Csvagnotti, ainsi que 157 passagers de 3me classe. Per Moss 3.8. Tabor, arrived to day fro or Liverpool.-— Mr. H. C. Moss, Mr. J. B. Andrews, Mr. and Mrs N. Khoori and 9 children, M. A. Baron, Mr. J. Milani, Mr. Ma Veils Mme Jolie Mailer, Sisters della Crocs Charruoh, Aubert, Mr. H. R Clarks Mr. A. C. Albaoi, Mr. H. Shirt, Mr. J. Bai - worth, Sergt J. H. Hendry, Mr. A Bonici and 22 deck passengers.
DEPARTURES
Sont partis le 12 septembre 1906 par le paquebot Osmanieh de la Khedival Mail Line les passagers auivants:

Mr. and Mrs. Parkinson, M. Ahmed, bey, Emin, Mr. and Mrs. Rees, Mr. and Mrs. Spurgeon, Mme et Mlle Gregoridias, Tewfick bey, Tewfick eff. Fahmy, MM. Bereketi, Constantin Francesco. Cberido. Poriasi, Tonniols Hilmi effend:, Mohamed Cbafik, Bonne Mme Ralli, Miss Zoarotaki, Mme Zakos et 80 de

div.head: "EGYPT FOR THE EGYPTIANS."
div.p: (Suite et Fin)

On noos a aocotés da recevoir notre ssot d’ordre de Constautioople pares que nous avons soutenu la ee»re de la Turquie dans l'affaire de Tabah. Mais je voudraie bien savoir si les célèbres adversaires du régime turc actuel, Ahmed Riza bey, Ismail Kernel bey et Khalil Kbaled effendi, sont des agente de Yildiz pour avoir sonseno publiquement la Turquie dans oatte affaire ' Bt par qei les / écrirai ns anglais qui ont adopté notre asanièrr de voir oot-iU été inspirés t ions au servies des Boers et des pour avoir sympathisé avec eux et admiré leur étonnant oourage et leur admirable patriotisme t Aurait-il été vraiment patriotique de cotre part de soutenir 1'Argleterro contre la Tarqaie t Y a-t-il on seol Français qui admettrait qne ses compatriotes soient avso l'Allemagne contra la Rassie si ans lotte s'engageait entre oes deux peys 1 Bt si non» avons pris parti pour la Pranos dans le oonflit de Pachode pourquoi s'étonner de noos voir aveo la Torqnie dans la question de Tabah t Noos avons soutenu la oaure turque parce qae nous âvoas jsgé que le droit était de son côté. Et pois il aurait fallu noos prendre pour des naïfs et deg ignorante pour nous faire oroire qne la politiqas anglaise, qni noos a ravi 1e Bondan et les ports de U mer Ronge défendait les droits de l'Egypte à Tabah 1 Dire qne noos voulons voir les Tores aaltree de l'Egypte est ans absurdité. Ce que noua voulons, o’eat voir 1a question d’Egypte posée définitivement devant l’Europe Tontes les paissances ont des intérêts considérables en Egypte. Son sort ne pent donc dépendre de noos seals et après l’évaeoetion de notre territoire par Us troupes anglaises U question n'sura qu’uns seule solution : U rétablissement des droits oonférés à l’Bgypte par U traité ds Londres de 1840 et par Us firmans impériaux, en dotant U pays d'une Constitution libérals

Depuis l'aooord Ébglo-français quelques journalistes français opt era de leur devoir de mener en Egypte one campagne favorabU à l'occupation anglaise. D'entres voulant sans doute servir Uars-propraa intérêts, ont aooen- toé U note et ont osé nier l'existenoe d’une patrie égyptienne Cette attitude ne nous a ni étonnés ni désolés ayant déjh vn des hommes politiques occupent de hautes situations, faire de même. Plus nous avançons, pins noos comptons snr nos propres foras. Mais les attaques de ois journalistes ont fait U pins grand mal à U France parmi U olasse éclairée ainsi que parmi U peupla 8'iU voulaient réellement - servir lenr pays, eas journalistes enraient dû comprendra qne l’élite de U nation égyptienne a été instruite en France ou par des Français, qa'elU forme U premier fsetear du progrès et U seal intermédiaire possible entre les Européens et U people égyptien et que U Prance a U droit d'être fièra d’avoir ainsi - oo itrihné à réveiller l’Bgypta et b loi donner nne conscienoe nationale "Tout homme impartial reconnaît qne oe n'est pas nous qni avons changé da politiqas mais bien oenx qni d’adversaires implaoalla de U diplomatie anglaise sont devenus ses meilleors amis et auxiliaires. Ce n'eat pas noos qni avons sacrifié notre amitié envers U Pranos pour chercher d'antres amis. Csst U Prsnoe qui noua a abandonnée. II est dono bien compréhensible qae nous noos sentions lésés par une politique qui noua a fait tant de msL Mais o'est une erreur de oroire que nous avoua ooblié le passé, l’histoire et tout oe que la France a fait en Egypte. Noassavoas distinguer entre la Franoe poli tique et la Franoe scientifique et littéraire. On none dit qne bois attaquons la Franoe' dans nos éorits. Or, il faut nons lire poor nons comprendre Noos critiquons tout oe qni noas garait critiquable. Entre là critique et l'atteque il y a une bien grande différence. Noos essayore d’éolairer les pnisaanoee européennes snr les vraies souffrances da leurs sujete et nous sommes convaincus de faire one oeuvra utile et humanitaire. Voulant attirer l’attention delà France sur leor état, des Taniaiens et des Algériens adressent parfois des lettres aox jonrnanx moral- mans d'Egypte. Bst-ce nn crime î Je ne crois pas qu’il y ait en Franoe on d'Btet qui soit partisan da 1a
L'auteur de l'article sorle affirmé que je suis devenu un l’AUemagne que je reç is même , __ des diplomates allemande et qne M. Mu
